title: 114_hr5480
content: The Act is titled the "Boosting Equity for the American Middle Class Act of 2016" or the "BEAM Act of 2016." It introduces a refundable credit for early principal payments on certain home mortgages under a new section 36C of the Internal Revenue Code. The "BEAM Act of 2016" introduces a credit for excess home mortgage principal payments made by individuals, allowing a 50% credit on such payments, with an annual limit of $500. There is also a lifetime limitation where no credit is allowed if it was claimed for 10 preceding years, and a reduction based on modified adjusted gross income. The BEAM Act of 2016 introduces a credit for excess home mortgage principal payments made by individuals, allowing a 50% credit on such payments, with an annual limit of $500. The credit is subject to a lifetime limitation where no credit is allowed if claimed for 10 preceding years, and a reduction based on modified adjusted gross income. The BEAM Act of 2016 introduces a credit for excess home mortgage principal payments made by individuals, allowing a 50% credit on such payments, with an annual limit of $500. The credit is subject to a lifetime limitation where no credit is allowed if claimed for 10 preceding years, and a reduction based on modified adjusted gross income. Qualified home mortgage indebtedness refers to acquisition indebtedness on the primary residence of the taxpayer that constitutes a traditional mortgage. The term 'traditional mortgage' refers to a debt with a term of 15-30 years, with equal payments at regular intervals. Married individuals must file joint returns to claim a credit under this section. The credit under subsection (a) for joint returns is treated as allowed to both spouses. Excess home mortgage principal payments must be reported as defined in section 36C(e). The text discusses amendments related to excess home mortgage principal payments under section 36C(e) and includes conforming amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years ending after the enactment of this Act.
